Line 158: Line 158:
* [[Abdallah al-Qahdi]], a senior military general from Aden<ref>Finn, Tom (21 March 2011). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/21/yemen-military-commanders-opposition-tanks "Yemen Military Commanders Join Opposition as Tanks Take to the Streets]. ''[[The Guardian]]''.</ref>
* [[Abdallah al-Qahdi]], a senior military general from Aden<ref>Finn, Tom (21 March 2011). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/21/yemen-military-commanders-opposition-tanks "Yemen Military Commanders Join Opposition as Tanks Take to the Streets]. ''[[The Guardian]]''.</ref>
â
==Opposition factions==
+
==International reactions==
  +
* {{flagicon|Canada}} On 6 March, the [[Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade|Canadian Foreign Affairs and International Trade Department]] said, "Canadians should leave Yemen as soon as possible, the Department of Foreign Affairs reiterated Sunday, as new political violence swept the Middle Eastern nation."<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | title = Leave Yemen, Ottawa Warns Canadians | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/03/06/yemen-travel-warning.html | publisher = [[CBC News]] | date = 6 March 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
* {{flagicon|UK}} On 19 February, the [[BBC News]] reported that [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|U.K. Foreign Secretary]] [[William Hague]] said he was "deeply concerned" by the "unacceptable violence" used against protesters.<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12514696 |title = Hague Condemns Violence in Libya, Bahrain and Yemen | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 19 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref> On 18 February, the [[government of the United Kingdom|UK government]] had announced that in light of the unrest it was considering revoking some arms export licenses stating that "licenses will not be issued when officials judge that there is a risk that the exports may provoke regional or internal conflicts or be used to facilitate internal repression".<ref>{{cite web | author = Staff | title = Bahrain Forces Fire at Protesters – Troops Open Live Fire Around Pearl Roundabout in Manama after Nightfall, at Least 66 Wounded | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date = 18 February 2011 | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112184122210251.html | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
* {{flagicon|USA}} On 18 February, [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] said that he was "deeply concerned" by the violence.<ref>{{cite web | author = Carey, Glen; Alexander, Caroline | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-17/bahrain-security-forces-kill-two-people-overnight-human-rights-groups-say.html | title = Bahrain's King Seeks Talks With Foes Amid Clashes in Region | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 18 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
:During a trip to Yemen,{{when|date=May 2011|reason=needs context}} [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said she would be working not just at a military cooperation but also a "comprehensive strategy" aimed at resolving Yemen's "myriad problems". She also said that "Yemen recognises the threat AQAP poses to it and it has become increasingly committed to a broad-based counter-terrorism strategy. At the same time, we are committed to a balanced approach towards Yemen which includes social, economic and political assistance. We face a common threat by the terrorists in Al-Qaeda. We are focused not just on short-term threats but on long-term challenges." She also signaled a "joint vision for a unified, stable, democratic and prosperous Yemen where civil society had the room to operate and Al-Qaeda did not."<ref>{{dead link|date=May 2011}} {{cite web|author = | url =http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=169704&language=en |title = Clinton in Yemen: We Face Common Terrorist Threat 11/01/2011 |publisher = [[Al-Manar]] |date = 14 January 2011 | accessdate = 1 February 2011}}</ref> On 27 January, [[Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs|US Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs]] [[Philip J. Crowley]] told reporters that the US government backed the right of Yemenis to "express themselves and assemble freely".<ref name="US backs Yemenis">{{cite news
  +
| url= http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jO7qKYr540pwAsWnx-eTCpjpoxUg?docId=CNG.b27ce982d5a2c46fdde0c964ca0fcea9.ef1
  +
| title = US Backs Yemeni Right To Protest
  +
| author = Staff | publisher = [[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[Google News]])
  +
| date = 27 January 2011
  +
| accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref> The US also later said that it had hopes reform attempts would stave off protests similar to Egypt.<ref>{{dead link|date=May 2011}} {{cite news | author = | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/03/AR2011020300546.html | title = US Officials: US-Egypt Discuss Mubarak Quitting | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = | accessdate = 4 February 2011}}</ref> On 18 February, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that the [[U.S. Embassy, Sana'a|US Embassy in Sana'a]] wrote in a statement that it had seen "a disturbing rise in the number and violence of attacks against Yemeni citizens gathering peacefully to express their views on the current political situation", adding, "We have also seen reports that Government of Yemen officials were present during these attacks", and asked the Yemeni government to "prevent any further attacks on peaceful demonstrations".<ref name="Sudarsan Raghavan">{{cite news
  +
| url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/18/AR2011021804066.html
  +
| title = In Yemen, Government Loyalists Harden Their Attacks on Protesters
  +
| author = Raghavan, Sudarsan | work = [[The Washington Post]]
  +
| date = 18 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
:On 1 March, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that after cleric [[Abdul Majid al-Zindani]], a one-time mentor of [[Osama bin Laden]], publicly called for an Islamic state to replace Saleh, [[Garry Reid]], the Deputy Assistant [[Secretary of Defense for Special Operations and Combating Terrorism]], said Saleh's government was "the best partner we'll have ''[against al-Qaeda]'', and hopefully it will survive".<ref>{{registration required|date=May 2011}} {{cite news | title = Powerful Cleric Urges Islamic Rule in Yemen | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/02/world/middleeast/02yemen.html|accessdate = 2 March 2011 | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = 1 March 2011 | author = Kasinof, Laura; Shane, Scott}}</ref>
  +   +
;Financial markets
  +
On 2 February, [[Brent Crude]] crossed US$100 on concern over instability.<ref>{{cite web | author = Lawler, Alex | url = http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Brent-oil-tops-103-on-Egypt-violence-Yemen-2011-02-03T114224Z-UPDATE-6 | title = Brent Oil Tops $103 on Egypt Violence, Yemen – Update 6 | publisher = [[Reuters]] (via [[forexyard.com]]) | date = 4 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref> The following day, crude oil rose for the fifth day in a row on speculation of spreading protests and the prospect of uncertainty.<ref>{{cite web | author = Regan, Michael P.; Nazareth, Rita | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/japanese-stocks-decline-on-earnings-unrest-in-egypt-crude-copper-climb.html | title = Euro Slides as Trichet Damps Rate-Increase Speculation; U.S. Stocks Fall | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 3 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
Regional financial stock market indices fell on 20 February on concern of spreading instability.<ref>{{cite web | author = Hankir, Zahra | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-20/dubai-shares-drop-most-this-month-on-growing-mideast-unrest-emaar-falls.html | title = Dubai Shares Drop as Mideast Unrest Sparks Risk Aversion; Emaar, Zain Fall | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 20 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
==Analysis==
  +   +
===Opposition factions===
{{See also|Political parties in Yemen}}
{{See also|Political parties in Yemen}}
According to [[Al Jazeera English]] in late February, the deeply fractured opposition includes the [[Joint Meeting Parties]] (JMP; formed in 2002), [[al-Islah|Islah]] (also known as Yemeni Congregation for Reform and the major member of JMP), the al-Ahmar family, and various insurrection groups including the [[Houthis]] in the north and the [[South Yemen Movement]] in the south. These groups include socialist, Islamist and tribal elements with differing goals. Islah, which [[Yemeni parliamentary election, 2003|currently holds about twenty per cent]] of the seats in the legislature, includes some members of the Ahmar family, Yemen's [[Muslim Brotherhood#Yemen|Muslim Brotherhood]], and [[Salafi]] preacher [[Abdul Majid al-Zindani]], labeled a "specially designated global terrorist" by the US. The JMP also includes the Yemeni Socialist Party (YSP), Al-Haq, the Unionist party, and the Popular Forces Union party. The al-Ahmar sons – [[Sadek al-Ahmar]] and [[Hamid al-Ahmar]] – whose late father was a former leader of the Hashid tribal confederation, want power. The Southern Movement has temporarily dropped its calls for secession with calls for Saleh's ouster.<ref>Staff (28 February 2011). [http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/yemen/2011/02/2011228141453986337.html "Who's Who in Yemen's Opposition – As Protests Against Ali Abdullah Saleh Continue, Opposition Remains Fractured, Riven with Differences"]. [[Al Jazeera English]]. Retrieved 16 May 2011.</ref>
According to [[Al Jazeera English]] in late February, the deeply fractured opposition includes the [[Joint Meeting Parties]] (JMP; formed in 2002), [[al-Islah|Islah]] (also known as Yemeni Congregation for Reform and the major member of JMP), the al-Ahmar family, and various insurrection groups including the [[Houthis]] in the north and the [[South Yemen Movement]] in the south. These groups include socialist, Islamist and tribal elements with differing goals. Islah, which [[Yemeni parliamentary election, 2003|currently holds about twenty per cent]] of the seats in the legislature, includes some members of the Ahmar family, Yemen's [[Muslim Brotherhood#Yemen|Muslim Brotherhood]], and [[Salafi]] preacher [[Abdul Majid al-Zindani]], labeled a "specially designated global terrorist" by the US. The JMP also includes the Yemeni Socialist Party (YSP), Al-Haq, the Unionist party, and the Popular Forces Union party. The al-Ahmar sons – [[Sadek al-Ahmar]] and [[Hamid al-Ahmar]] – whose late father was a former leader of the Hashid tribal confederation, want power. The Southern Movement has temporarily dropped its calls for secession with calls for Saleh's ouster.<ref>Staff (28 February 2011). [http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/yemen/2011/02/2011228141453986337.html "Who's Who in Yemen's Opposition – As Protests Against Ali Abdullah Saleh Continue, Opposition Remains Fractured, Riven with Differences"]. [[Al Jazeera English]]. Retrieved 16 May 2011.</ref>
Line 166: Line 166:
On 21 March, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported that in the absence of obvious candidates for the presidency, the transition of power is likely to be controlled by those who made the pre-emptive strike against him: [[Hamid al-Ahmar]] of Islah and the JMP, radical cleric [[Abdul Majid al-Zindani]], and Islamist-allied General [[Ali Mohsen al-Ahmar]] (also called [[Ali Mohsen Saleh]]).<ref>{{registration required|date=May 2011}} Fielding-Smith, Abigail; Khalaf, Roula (21 March 2011). [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f4a1f49e-53f0-11e0-8bd7-00144feab49a.html#axzz1HO6jZuzd "Feared General Regarded as Kingmaker"]. ''[[Financial Times]]''. Retrieved 21 March 2011.</ref>
On 21 March, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported that in the absence of obvious candidates for the presidency, the transition of power is likely to be controlled by those who made the pre-emptive strike against him: [[Hamid al-Ahmar]] of Islah and the JMP, radical cleric [[Abdul Majid al-Zindani]], and Islamist-allied General [[Ali Mohsen al-Ahmar]] (also called [[Ali Mohsen Saleh]]).<ref>{{registration required|date=May 2011}} Fielding-Smith, Abigail; Khalaf, Roula (21 March 2011). [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f4a1f49e-53f0-11e0-8bd7-00144feab49a.html#axzz1HO6jZuzd "Feared General Regarded as Kingmaker"]. ''[[Financial Times]]''. Retrieved 21 March 2011.</ref>
â
===Southern groups===
+
====Southern groups====
Southern secessionist groups said they were holding three Yemeni soldiers kidnapped towards the end of January. On 2 February, clashes in the south also resulted in three injuries.<ref>{{cite web | author = Staff | date = 2 February 2011 | url = http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iny54OZvAJq5sX9zhloNLQxiGxvA?docId=CNG.4aae4371b956b57599c1a3203f206025.3f1 | title = Three Wounded in South Yemen Clashes | publisher = [[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[Google News]]) | accessdate = 16 May 2011}}</ref> A growing number of protesters in the north sees with interest the rise of the [[South Yemen Movement]], maybe hoping that the southern secessionists may overthrow the government.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
Southern secessionist groups said they were holding three Yemeni soldiers kidnapped towards the end of January. On 2 February, clashes in the south also resulted in three injuries.<ref>{{cite web | author = Staff | date = 2 February 2011 | url = http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iny54OZvAJq5sX9zhloNLQxiGxvA?docId=CNG.4aae4371b956b57599c1a3203f206025.3f1 | title = Three Wounded in South Yemen Clashes | publisher = [[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[Google News]]) | accessdate = 16 May 2011}}</ref> A growing number of protesters in the north sees with interest the rise of the [[South Yemen Movement]], maybe hoping that the southern secessionists may overthrow the government.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
â
===Al Qaeda===
+
====Al Qaeda====
On 6 March, [[Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] (AQAP) claimed responsibility for the shooting of five soldiers two separate attacks during the ongoing protests. Four of the soldiers were killed in [[Marib province]] when the perpetrators opened fire on a passing military vehicle. Two of the soldiers were part of the [[Republican Guard]]. The other death was that of an army colonel who was shot as he went shopping in [[Zinjibar]], [[Abyan Governorate]].<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113685346945172.html |title=Yemeni Soldiers Killed in Attacks – Five Dead in Suspected al-Qaeda Attacks as Protests Continue Against Saleh's Decades-Long Grip on Power | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date = 6 March 2011 |accessdate = 16 May 2011}}</ref>
On 6 March, [[Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] (AQAP) claimed responsibility for the shooting of five soldiers two separate attacks during the ongoing protests. Four of the soldiers were killed in [[Marib province]] when the perpetrators opened fire on a passing military vehicle. Two of the soldiers were part of the [[Republican Guard]]. The other death was that of an army colonel who was shot as he went shopping in [[Zinjibar]], [[Abyan Governorate]].<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113685346945172.html |title=Yemeni Soldiers Killed in Attacks – Five Dead in Suspected al-Qaeda Attacks as Protests Continue Against Saleh's Decades-Long Grip on Power | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date = 6 March 2011 |accessdate = 16 May 2011}}</ref>
On 31 March 2011, AQAP declared an "Islamic [[Emirate]]" in the southern [[Abyan Governorate]].<ref>{{verify credibility|date=May 2011|reason=what are credentials of eurasiareview.com? seemingly no wiki article to use to assess; unable to locate "about us" module on its site. "albawaba" has wiki article; surely direct attribution is available from its own site?}} {{cite news | author = Staff | url = http://www.eurasiareview.com/yemen-al-qaeda-declares-south-province-as-islamic-emirate-31032011/ | title = Yemen: Al Qaeda Declares South Province As 'Islamic Emirate' | publisher = [[Al Bawaba]] (via [[Eurasia Review]]) | date = 31 March 2011 | accessdate = 16 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = Craig, Iona | url = http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-04-01-yemen01_ST_N.htm?csp=34news | title = Amid Region's Unrest, al-Qaeda Makes Inroads in Yemen | work = [[USA Today]] | date = 1 April 2011 | accessdate = 16 May 2011}}</ref>
On 31 March 2011, AQAP declared an "Islamic [[Emirate]]" in the southern [[Abyan Governorate]].<ref>{{verify credibility|date=May 2011|reason=what are credentials of eurasiareview.com? seemingly no wiki article to use to assess; unable to locate "about us" module on its site. "albawaba" has wiki article; surely direct attribution is available from its own site?}} {{cite news | author = Staff | url = http://www.eurasiareview.com/yemen-al-qaeda-declares-south-province-as-islamic-emirate-31032011/ | title = Yemen: Al Qaeda Declares South Province As 'Islamic Emirate' | publisher = [[Al Bawaba]] (via [[Eurasia Review]]) | date = 31 March 2011 | accessdate = 16 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = Craig, Iona | url = http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-04-01-yemen01_ST_N.htm?csp=34news | title = Amid Region's Unrest, al-Qaeda Makes Inroads in Yemen | work = [[USA Today]] | date = 1 April 2011 | accessdate = 16 May 2011}}</ref>
â
===Joint Meeting Parties===
+
====Joint Meeting Parties====
On 2 March, six members of the JMP issued a five-point list of demands: right to demonstrate, investigations into violence, peaceful transition of government, time schedule within current year, and dialogue with those both inside and outside of Yemen.<ref name=autogenerated3>[http://www.yemenpeaceproject.org/wordpress/?p=263 "San'a Bulletin #4"]. The Yemen Peace Project. 3 March 2011.</ref>
On 2 March, six members of the JMP issued a five-point list of demands: right to demonstrate, investigations into violence, peaceful transition of government, time schedule within current year, and dialogue with those both inside and outside of Yemen.<ref name=autogenerated3>[http://www.yemenpeaceproject.org/wordpress/?p=263 "San'a Bulletin #4"]. The Yemen Peace Project. 3 March 2011.</ref>
On 4 April, the JMP issued a statement that any new regime, after Saleh's fall, would be a strong ally in the "War on Terror".<ref>[http://www.yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=3383&MainCat=3" Opposition Assures Any 'New Regime Will Be Strong Ally in War on Terror'"]. ''[[Yemen Post]]''. 4 April 2011.</ref>
On 4 April, the JMP issued a statement that any new regime, after Saleh's fall, would be a strong ally in the "War on Terror".<ref>[http://www.yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=3383&MainCat=3" Opposition Assures Any 'New Regime Will Be Strong Ally in War on Terror'"]. ''[[Yemen Post]]''. 4 April 2011.</ref>
â
===Student protesters===
+
====Student protesters====
The students have focused on secular demands for an end to corruption and oppression. Starting in February, there were concerns that Islah, part of the JMP political group, was attempting to co-opt the student protests. There were chants of âNo GPC, No Islahâ after al-Zindani's speech on 28 February, in which he renounced President Saleh and spoke of the return of the Islamic caliphate. There were also doubts about some of the government resignations being truly in support of the student protesters.<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref>Kasinof, Laura (1 March 2011). [http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0301/Yemen-students-to-politicians-Don-t-hijack-our-revolution "Yemen Students to Politicians: Don't Hijack Our Revolution"]. ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]''.</ref><ref>[http://www.yemenpeaceproject.org/wordpress/?p=269 Sanâa Bulletin #5], The Yemen Peace Project, 8 March 2011.</ref>
The students have focused on secular demands for an end to corruption and oppression. Starting in February, there were concerns that Islah, part of the JMP political group, was attempting to co-opt the student protests. There were chants of âNo GPC, No Islahâ after al-Zindani's speech on 28 February, in which he renounced President Saleh and spoke of the return of the Islamic caliphate. There were also doubts about some of the government resignations being truly in support of the student protesters.<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref>Kasinof, Laura (1 March 2011). [http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0301/Yemen-students-to-politicians-Don-t-hijack-our-revolution "Yemen Students to Politicians: Don't Hijack Our Revolution"]. ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]''.</ref><ref>[http://www.yemenpeaceproject.org/wordpress/?p=269 Sanâa Bulletin #5], The Yemen Peace Project, 8 March 2011.</ref>
On 13 March, a coordination council of the Sana'a University protestors presented a list of seven demands, starting with the removal of Saleh and the creation of a temporary presidential council made up of representatives drawn from Yemenâs four main political powers along with one appointed by the national security and military establishment. Many members of the Revolutionary Coalition of Youth for Peaceful Change (12 organizations) and the Organization of Liberal Yemeni Youth appear to be represented by this coordination counil.<ref>Al-Sakkaf, Nadia (14 March 2011). [http://www.yementimes.com/defaultdet.aspx?SUB_ID=35747 "Yemeni Youth Movements Consolidate"].''[[Yemen Times]]''</ref> On 17 March they sent a letter to US President Barack Obama, copying British PM David Cameron and EU President John Bruton, explaining their group, positions and proposals.<ref>Novak, Jane (22 March 2011). [http://armiesofliberation.com/archives/2011/03/22/yemens-youth-coordinating-council-writes-president-obama/ "Yemenâs Youth Coordinating Council Writes President Obama"]. [[Armies of Liberation]]. 22 March 2011.</ref>
On 13 March, a coordination council of the Sana'a University protestors presented a list of seven demands, starting with the removal of Saleh and the creation of a temporary presidential council made up of representatives drawn from Yemenâs four main political powers along with one appointed by the national security and military establishment. Many members of the Revolutionary Coalition of Youth for Peaceful Change (12 organizations) and the Organization of Liberal Yemeni Youth appear to be represented by this coordination counil.<ref>Al-Sakkaf, Nadia (14 March 2011). [http://www.yementimes.com/defaultdet.aspx?SUB_ID=35747 "Yemeni Youth Movements Consolidate"].''[[Yemen Times]]''</ref> On 17 March they sent a letter to US President Barack Obama, copying British PM David Cameron and EU President John Bruton, explaining their group, positions and proposals.<ref>Novak, Jane (22 March 2011). [http://armiesofliberation.com/archives/2011/03/22/yemens-youth-coordinating-council-writes-president-obama/ "Yemenâs Youth Coordinating Council Writes President Obama"]. [[Armies of Liberation]]. 22 March 2011.</ref>
â
===National Dialogue Committee===
+
====National Dialogue Committee====
On 20 March, the National Dialogue Committee issued a position paper and list of demands. Their members are the JMP, independents, some [[General People's Congress (Yemen)|General People's Congress]] members, and social figures including political, tribal and businessmen. It is headed by Mr. [[Mohammed Salem Basandwah]], an adviser to the president, and Sheik [[Hameed Al-Ahmer]] of Islah is its Secretary General.<ref>Novak, Jane (20 March 2011). [http://armiesofliberation.com/archives/2010/03/20/the-yemeni-national-dialog-committee-issues-vision-for-national-salvation/ "The Yemeni National Dialog Committee Issues Vision for National Salvation"]. [[Armies of Liberation]].</ref>
On 20 March, the National Dialogue Committee issued a position paper and list of demands. Their members are the JMP, independents, some [[General People's Congress (Yemen)|General People's Congress]] members, and social figures including political, tribal and businessmen. It is headed by Mr. [[Mohammed Salem Basandwah]], an adviser to the president, and Sheik [[Hameed Al-Ahmer]] of Islah is its Secretary General.<ref>Novak, Jane (20 March 2011). [http://armiesofliberation.com/archives/2010/03/20/the-yemeni-national-dialog-committee-issues-vision-for-national-salvation/ "The Yemeni National Dialog Committee Issues Vision for National Salvation"]. [[Armies of Liberation]].</ref>
â
===Civil Bloc===
+
====Civil Bloc====
On 24 March, the Civil Bloc, an umbrella group of civil society organisations, called for a transitional council of nine figures "not involved with the corruption of the old regime" to draw up a new constitution over a six-month period ahead of elections.<ref>Johnston, Cynthia; Ghobari, Mohammed (24 March 2011. [http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/03/24/idINIndia-55848220110324 "Yemen Forces Clash over Saleh Before Friday Protest"]. [[Reuters]].</ref>
On 24 March, the Civil Bloc, an umbrella group of civil society organisations, called for a transitional council of nine figures "not involved with the corruption of the old regime" to draw up a new constitution over a six-month period ahead of elections.<ref>Johnston, Cynthia; Ghobari, Mohammed (24 March 2011. [http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/03/24/idINIndia-55848220110324 "Yemen Forces Clash over Saleh Before Friday Protest"]. [[Reuters]].</ref>
â
===Arrests and repression===
+
====Arrests and repression====
[[File:Yemen protest3.jpg|thumb|A television reporter in the middle of protesters in [[Sana'a]] on 3 February.]]
[[File:Yemen protest3.jpg|thumb|A television reporter in the middle of protesters in [[Sana'a]] on 3 February.]]
On 23 January, Tawakel Karman was detained and charged with "'inciting disorder and chaos' and organising unauthorised demonstrations and marches".<ref name="ifex_karman_freed">{{cite web | author = | title = Authorities Release Journalists for Fear of Tunisia-Style Unrest | publisher =[[International Freedom of Expression Exchange]] | date = 26 January 2011 | url =http://www.ifex.org/yemen/2011/01/26/karman_released/ | accessdate = 1 February 2011 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wBItIgt2 | archivedate = 1 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Karman was a leader of two student rallies in Sana'a and called for the overthrow of Saleh's regime.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained"/> Her husband said her whereabouts were not known.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained" /> Several hundred students protested outside Sana'a University demanding her release.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained" /> Thousands of people protested against the arrest of Karman and other protestors by a sit-in outside of the prosecutor's office. She was freed 30 hours after her arrest on parole, with the condition not to violate "public order and the law".<ref name="ifex_karman_freed" /> Karman returned to participating in demonstrations hours after her release.<ref name="ifex_karman_freed" />
On 23 January, Tawakel Karman was detained and charged with "'inciting disorder and chaos' and organising unauthorised demonstrations and marches".<ref name="ifex_karman_freed">{{cite web | author = | title = Authorities Release Journalists for Fear of Tunisia-Style Unrest | publisher =[[International Freedom of Expression Exchange]] | date = 26 January 2011 | url =http://www.ifex.org/yemen/2011/01/26/karman_released/ | accessdate = 1 February 2011 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wBItIgt2 | archivedate = 1 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Karman was a leader of two student rallies in Sana'a and called for the overthrow of Saleh's regime.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained"/> Her husband said her whereabouts were not known.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained" /> Several hundred students protested outside Sana'a University demanding her release.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained" /> Thousands of people protested against the arrest of Karman and other protestors by a sit-in outside of the prosecutor's office. She was freed 30 hours after her arrest on parole, with the condition not to violate "public order and the law".<ref name="ifex_karman_freed" /> Karman returned to participating in demonstrations hours after her release.<ref name="ifex_karman_freed" />
Line 196: Line 196:
On 14 March, security forces raided an apartment shared by four Western journalists and deported them. [[Reporters Without Borders]] condemned the action and noted that two other foreign journalists were also deported two days earlier. The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] also condemned the expulsions. They also said that two Yemeni journalists informed them that a group of twenty people, believed to be government supporters, went to the Journalists Syndicate in Sana'a a day earlier{{When|date=March 2011}} and threatened to burn it down.<ref name="AJYemen15Mar">{{cite news | title = Yemen Deports Foreign Journalists | publisher =[[Al-Jazeera English]] | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011314212132903514.html | date = 15 March 2011 | accessdate = 15 March 2011}}</ref> They further said that Yemeni journalists are facing increasing harassment.<ref>{{cite web | author = | title = Attacks on Journalists in Yemen, Sudan Amid Street Protests |url=http://cpj.org/2011/01/attacks-on-journalists-in-yemen-sudan-amid-street.php | publisher = [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] | date = | accessdate = 1 February 2011}}</ref>
On 14 March, security forces raided an apartment shared by four Western journalists and deported them. [[Reporters Without Borders]] condemned the action and noted that two other foreign journalists were also deported two days earlier. The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] also condemned the expulsions. They also said that two Yemeni journalists informed them that a group of twenty people, believed to be government supporters, went to the Journalists Syndicate in Sana'a a day earlier{{When|date=March 2011}} and threatened to burn it down.<ref name="AJYemen15Mar">{{cite news | title = Yemen Deports Foreign Journalists | publisher =[[Al-Jazeera English]] | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011314212132903514.html | date = 15 March 2011 | accessdate = 15 March 2011}}</ref> They further said that Yemeni journalists are facing increasing harassment.<ref>{{cite web | author = | title = Attacks on Journalists in Yemen, Sudan Amid Street Protests |url=http://cpj.org/2011/01/attacks-on-journalists-in-yemen-sudan-amid-street.php | publisher = [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] | date = | accessdate = 1 February 2011}}</ref>
â
==International reactions==
  â
* {{flagicon|Canada}} On 6 March, the [[Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade|Canadian Foreign Affairs and International Trade Department]] said, "Canadians should leave Yemen as soon as possible, the Department of Foreign Affairs reiterated Sunday, as new political violence swept the Middle Eastern nation."<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | title = Leave Yemen, Ottawa Warns Canadians | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/03/06/yemen-travel-warning.html | publisher = [[CBC News]] | date = 6 March 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
* {{flagicon|UK}} On 19 February, the [[BBC News]] reported that [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|U.K. Foreign Secretary]] [[William Hague]] said he was "deeply concerned" by the "unacceptable violence" used against protesters.<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12514696 |title = Hague Condemns Violence in Libya, Bahrain and Yemen | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 19 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref> On 18 February, the [[government of the United Kingdom|UK government]] had announced that in light of the unrest it was considering revoking some arms export licenses stating that "licenses will not be issued when officials judge that there is a risk that the exports may provoke regional or internal conflicts or be used to facilitate internal repression".<ref>{{cite web | author = Staff | title = Bahrain Forces Fire at Protesters – Troops Open Live Fire Around Pearl Roundabout in Manama after Nightfall, at Least 66 Wounded | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date = 18 February 2011 | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112184122210251.html | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
* {{flagicon|USA}} On 18 February, [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] said that he was "deeply concerned" by the violence.<ref>{{cite web | author = Carey, Glen; Alexander, Caroline | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-17/bahrain-security-forces-kill-two-people-overnight-human-rights-groups-say.html | title = Bahrain's King Seeks Talks With Foes Amid Clashes in Region | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 18 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
:During a trip to Yemen,{{when|date=May 2011|reason=needs context}} [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said she would be working not just at a military cooperation but also a "comprehensive strategy" aimed at resolving Yemen's "myriad problems". She also said that "Yemen recognises the threat AQAP poses to it and it has become increasingly committed to a broad-based counter-terrorism strategy. At the same time, we are committed to a balanced approach towards Yemen which includes social, economic and political assistance. We face a common threat by the terrorists in Al-Qaeda. We are focused not just on short-term threats but on long-term challenges." She also signaled a "joint vision for a unified, stable, democratic and prosperous Yemen where civil society had the room to operate and Al-Qaeda did not."<ref>{{dead link|date=May 2011}} {{cite web|author = | url =http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=169704&language=en |title = Clinton in Yemen: We Face Common Terrorist Threat 11/01/2011 |publisher = [[Al-Manar]] |date = 14 January 2011 | accessdate = 1 February 2011}}</ref> On 27 January, [[Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs|US Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs]] [[Philip J. Crowley]] told reporters that the US government backed the right of Yemenis to "express themselves and assemble freely".<ref name="US backs Yemenis">{{cite news
  â
| url= http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jO7qKYr540pwAsWnx-eTCpjpoxUg?docId=CNG.b27ce982d5a2c46fdde0c964ca0fcea9.ef1
  â
| title = US Backs Yemeni Right To Protest
  â
| author = Staff | publisher = [[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[Google News]])
  â
| date = 27 January 2011
  â
| accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref> The US also later said that it had hopes reform attempts would stave off protests similar to Egypt.<ref>{{dead link|date=May 2011}} {{cite news | author = | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/03/AR2011020300546.html | title = US Officials: US-Egypt Discuss Mubarak Quitting | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = | accessdate = 4 February 2011}}</ref> On 18 February, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that the [[U.S. Embassy, Sana'a|US Embassy in Sana'a]] wrote in a statement that it had seen "a disturbing rise in the number and violence of attacks against Yemeni citizens gathering peacefully to express their views on the current political situation", adding, "We have also seen reports that Government of Yemen officials were present during these attacks", and asked the Yemeni government to "prevent any further attacks on peaceful demonstrations".<ref name="Sudarsan Raghavan">{{cite news
  â
| url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/18/AR2011021804066.html
  â
| title = In Yemen, Government Loyalists Harden Their Attacks on Protesters
  â
| author = Raghavan, Sudarsan | work = [[The Washington Post]]
  â
| date = 18 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
:On 1 March, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that after cleric [[Abdul Majid al-Zindani]], a one-time mentor of [[Osama bin Laden]], publicly called for an Islamic state to replace Saleh, [[Garry Reid]], the Deputy Assistant [[Secretary of Defense for Special Operations and Combating Terrorism]], said Saleh's government was "the best partner we'll have ''[against al-Qaeda]'', and hopefully it will survive".<ref>{{registration required|date=May 2011}} {{cite news | title = Powerful Cleric Urges Islamic Rule in Yemen | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/02/world/middleeast/02yemen.html|accessdate = 2 March 2011 | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = 1 March 2011 | author = Kasinof, Laura; Shane, Scott}}</ref>
  â   â
;Financial markets
  â
On 2 February, [[Brent Crude]] crossed US$100 on concern over instability.<ref>{{cite web | author = Lawler, Alex | url = http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Brent-oil-tops-103-on-Egypt-violence-Yemen-2011-02-03T114224Z-UPDATE-6 | title = Brent Oil Tops $103 on Egypt Violence, Yemen – Update 6 | publisher = [[Reuters]] (via [[forexyard.com]]) | date = 4 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref> The following day, crude oil rose for the fifth day in a row on speculation of spreading protests and the prospect of uncertainty.<ref>{{cite web | author = Regan, Michael P.; Nazareth, Rita | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/japanese-stocks-decline-on-earnings-unrest-in-egypt-crude-copper-climb.html | title = Euro Slides as Trichet Damps Rate-Increase Speculation; U.S. Stocks Fall | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 3 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Regional financial stock market indices fell on 20 February on concern of spreading instability.<ref>{{cite web | author = Hankir, Zahra | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-20/dubai-shares-drop-most-this-month-on-growing-mideast-unrest-emaar-falls.html | title = Dubai Shares Drop as Mideast Unrest Sparks Risk Aversion; Emaar, Zain Fall | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 20 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 May 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
